info.game_comments: (Sofia: Clues about horses, next on Jeopardy!)

(1, 1).clue: He designed the writing box on which he wrote the Declaration of Independence

(3, 1).clue: It makes a blacksmith's job much easier that this part of the horse has no nerves

(4, 1).clue: This battered & deep-fried delight of meat on a stick dates from the 1940s

(5, 1).clue: In the 1990s this Chicago Bulls guard was the MVP of the NBA Finals a record 6 times

(6, 1).clue: Reportedly the Lapps were the first to depict Father Christmas with a sleigh drawn by these

(1, 2).clue: Appropriately, this state had only 2 signers, the fewest of the 13 states

(2, 2).correct response: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals

(3, 2).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew)  A horse's slowest natural gait is a walk; this is the next one up in speed

(4, 2).clue: In a bizarre twist of fate, George W. Bush almost choked on one of these on January 13, 2002

(5, 2).clue: In June 2002 this Lakers coach became the all-time leader in playoff victories by winning his 156th game

(6, 2).clue: This novelty hit begins, "Christmas, Christmas time is near, time for toys and time for cheer"

(1, 3).clue: Among other things, this ruler was taken to task "for imposing taxes on us without our consent"

(3, 3).clue: It can mean any small horse, but according to the AQPA it's one under 58 inches tall

(4, 3).clue: Chester, seen here, is the spokescat for this snack brand, launched nationally in 1948

(5, 3).clue: In 1995 this Houston Rockets center scored a then-record 131 points in a 4-game NBA Finals

(6, 3).clue: He first described Santa as "chubby and plump" & "a right jolly old elf"

(1, 4).clue: This is the first of the self-evident truths
(1, 4).correct response: that all men are created equal

(3, 4).clue: This horse breed was running around the peninsula of the same name as early as 2500 B.C.

(4, 4).clue: This word follows Hot, Lean & Croissant in the names of stuffed sandwiches from Chef America

(5, 4).clue: The NBA's Coach of the Year Trophy is named for this longtime Celtics coach

(6, 4).clue: This alternate name for old St. Nick came from the German for "Christ Child"

(1, 5).clue: This man presided over the debate leading to the Declaration; his namesake great-grandson was president, 1889-93

(3, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew)  This can be the circumference of the horse's chest, or the band I'm making nice & tight to keep the saddle in place

(4, 5).clue: O.D. McKee named this brand of snack cakes for his granddaughter, & its logo seen here bears her image

(5, 5).clue: In 1987 7'7" Manute Bol was a teammate of 5'3" Tyrone Bogues, better known by this nickname

(6, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew)  He began creating his own Christmas ornaments in the 1980s, & now sells over 1,200 designs like this one

(1, 1).clue: Coming from the West Bank, you might cross over Mount Pisgah to get to this capital city of Jordan

(2, 1).clue: Adapting pagan images, artists began putting pairs of these on angels to distinguish them from humans

(3, 1).clue: One of his most famous movie lines is "Of all the gin joints in all the towns in all the world, she walks into mine"

(4, 1).clue: In a criminal trial, a defendant's guilt must be proved "beyond" this

(5, 1).clue: Robert Leroy Parker used this famous alias when he rode with the Sundance Kid

(1, 2).clue: You can cross over the Dead Sea on your way to Jordan's Mount Nebo, where this biblical figure is said to have died

(2, 2).clue: In the 9 orders of angels, this group that includes Michael ranks second-lowest

(3, 2).clue: In "Taxi Driver" he asked himself, "You talking to me?  You talking to me?"

(4, 2).clue: 4-letter word for a charge or encumbrance placed on one's property to secure payment of a debt

(5, 2).clue: Nguyen Tat Thanh began using this alias around 1941 when he founded the Viet Minh

(1, 3).clue: You can cross the Jordan where it joins with the Yarmuk River just south of this "sea"

(2, 3).clue: The flowers seen here are called "the Angels' version of" this instrument

(3, 3).clue: At the end of "Little Caesar", this actor cries, "Mother of mercy, is this the end of Rico?"

(4, 3).clue: This adjective means "having left a will"; add the letters "in" & it means "without making a will"

(5, 3).clue: This man was using the alias Thomas Howard when Bob Ford killed him in 1882

(1, 4).clue: Crossing Jordan from north to south you'll start & end in these 2 countries that begin with the same letter

(2, 4).clue: A Latin word for "angel", it's a Catholic prayer & also the bell that's rung when you recite it

(3, 4).clue: In the best picture of '95, this actor exclaimed, "They may take our lives, but they'll never take our freedom!"

(4, 4).clue: The name of this writ that tells a lower court to butt out also applies to the 18th Amendment

(5, 4).clue: She adopted the alias Tania while robbing banks with the SLA

(6, 4).clue: Proverbially, you might be "a big fish in" one of these

(1, 5).clue: To cross over to Jordan from Egypt you can sail over this Red Sea gulf to the port city that bears its name

(2, 5).clue: In the "Inferno", an angel admits Dante & this poet-guide to the Sixth Circle of Hell

(3, 5).clue: In "My Favorite Year" he wails, "I'm not an actor, I'm a movie star!"

(4, 5).clue: This 2-word Latin phrase used as a plea means "I will not contest it"

(5, 5).clue: This Civil War guerrilla leader who wreaked havoc in Kansas used the alias Charles Hart

(6, 5).clue: It devastated overcrowded Scottish slums in the 19th century

(0, 0).clue: This state is 2nd in blueberry production, 3rd in cranberries, 4th in peaches but 1st in chemical production
